elements.title: Graduate Instinctual Renunciation Across the Phase Sequence
elements.problem: The host journey demands an escalating series of surrenders: identity disclosure at onboarding, private space codification at listing creation, emotional valuation at pricing, stranger admission at proposal management. But the platform presents these demands without regard for the cumulative psychological cost. A host in discovery has surrendered nothing; a host mid-listing-creation has surrendered identity, time, and is now converting intimate domestic space into a public marketplace artifact. When the platform treats each phase as an isolated task rather than as a position on a renunciation gradient, it underestimates the felt cost at later stages and overestimates the host's willingness to comply. The result is that dropout clusters at listing creation (the steepest point on the gradient), not because the task is technically difficult, but because the accumulated instinctual sacrifice peaks there.
elements.solution: Design the phase sequence so that the magnitude of each renunciation is matched by a proportional value delivery immediately preceding or accompanying it. Early phases should demand almost nothing (discovery shows value without requiring sign-up; evaluation demonstrates security before asking for commitment). Each subsequent phase should open with a concrete demonstration of what the prior renunciation purchased: onboarding shows the agent who will protect the host's interests; listing creation shows demand signals or comparable earnings before asking for photos; pricing shows what similar hosts earn before asking for a rate. The pattern is: at every step up the gradient, deliver a tangible civilizational benefit that justifies the next instinctual cost. Never allow two consecutive phases to demand without delivering.

evidence.quote: Any flow that requires users to give information before seeing results will lose most of them. Show something useful first. Offer to refine after.
evidence.insight: This UX principle is the surface expression of a deeper psychological law: instinctual renunciation without prior reward triggers the pleasure principle violation. The host's instinct to protect their privacy and autonomy can only be overcome if the platform has already demonstrated that previous surrenders produced something valuable.

evidence.quote: It is impossible to ignore the extent to which civilization is built up on renunciation of instinctual gratifications... This 'cultural privation' dominates the whole field of social relations between human beings; we know already that it is the cause of the antagonism against which all civilization has to fight.
evidence.insight: Freud identifies that every civilization must manage the antagonism produced by its own demands. The platform is a micro-civilization: it demands photos of private rooms, financial disclosures, acceptance of strangers. If it does not manage the antagonism at each step, hosts revolt against the platform just as Freud describes people revolting against civilization itself.

evidence.quote: Rod isn't sure people are willing to give all that information before they've seen any results. The platform needs to earn that trust first -- show them something, then invite them to refine.
evidence.insight: Rod's intuition maps directly to Freud's economics of the libido: the host will not renounce instinctual freedom (give information, surrender privacy) unless the platform has first demonstrated that the civilizational contract pays. The gradient must be value-led at every step.

elements.user_goal: Feel that each thing the platform asks me to give up is justified by something concrete it already gave me, so the overall experience feels like a fair exchange rather than a series of extractions.
elements.company_goal: Reduce listing creation abandonment by ensuring hosts arrive at the wizard's steepest demands (photos, rules, pricing) already convinced that the platform's value exceeds the instinctual cost of compliance.
elements.time_budget: Each value-delivery moment (earnings estimates, demand signals, agent introduction) should take under 10 seconds to absorb. The host should not be made to work for the reassurance; it should be presented automatically at each phase transition.
anti_goals: DO NOT demand two consecutive pieces of private information without an intervening value signal. Back-to-back asks without payoff feel like extraction, not exchange.
DO NOT front-load all value into discovery and then demand compliance through the remaining phases. Value delivery must be distributed across the full gradient.

DO NOT treat the renunciation gradient as a one-time design decision. Each new feature or form field added to any phase raises the gradient's height at that point and must be offset by proportional value.
elements.success_metric: Phase-to-phase continuation rate across the full sequence, with special attention to the evaluation-to-onboarding and onboarding-to-listing-creation transitions. Target: no single transition should drop below 60% continuation within the same session.

elements.title: Preserve Reversibility to Contain the Revolt Against Civilization
elements.problem: Freud identifies two distinct origins of the desire for freedom: one is a civilized revolt against a specific injustice (a host who pauses because a guest was problematic), and the other is a primitive instinctual need for autonomy (a host who simply wants their space back). The platform currently treats both the same way: the host can delete their listing (permanent) or leave silently (no mechanism for return). This binary forces every expression of freedom into a permanent exit. A host who experiences a momentary instinctual need for autonomy -- who simply wants to stop for a while -- is forced to either endure the discomfort or make it permanent. Freud predicts that forced permanence converts temporary resistance into lasting antagonism. The user stories document confirms this: 'Pause preserves the work, keeps the door open, and costs nothing. Delete is a one-way door that creates regret.'
elements.solution: Build reversibility into every phase where the host has made significant investment. The core mechanism is the Pause state: a listing that is invisible to the marketplace but fully preserved on the host's side, reactivatable without rebuilding. But the principle extends beyond listings. (1) At listing creation: allow saving an incomplete wizard at any step, with one-click resumption. (2) At active lease: allow hosts to signal they will not re-list after the current lease ends, without canceling the current lease or losing their listing data. (3) At retention: make reactivation as close to a single action as possible. The host who paused six months ago should be able to return and find everything as they left it. The psychological mechanism: reversibility reduces the felt cost of every renunciation because the host knows they can reclaim their instinctual freedom without losing what they have already built. The civilizational contract becomes tolerable when it is not a trap.

evidence.source: user-stories-initial-analysis.md, 'Pause matters more than delete' section
evidence.quote: Hosts who stop a listing aren't always done with it. Pause preserves the work, keeps the door open, and costs nothing. Delete is a one-way door that creates regret.
evidence.insight: Rod's observation is empirically grounded and psychologically precise: the host who pauses is expressing a need for temporary autonomy, not a permanent rejection of the marketplace. The platform must distinguish between these two signals and respond appropriately to each.

evidence.quote: The desire for freedom that makes itself felt in a human community may be a revolt against some existing injustice and so may prove favourable to a further development of civilization and remain compatible with it. But it may also have its origin in the primitive roots of the personality, still unfettered by civilizing influences, and so become a source of antagonism to culture.
evidence.insight: Freud distinguishes two types of freedom-seeking: constructive (revolt against injustice, compatible with civilization) and primitive (instinctual autonomy, antagonistic to civilization). The Pause mechanism accommodates both: the host who pauses due to a specific problem can return when it is resolved; the host who pauses due to instinctual fatigue can return when their desire for autonomy is satisfied. Both remain within the civilizational orbit.

evidence.quote: If the deprivation is not made good economically, one may be certain of producing serious disorders.
evidence.insight: Delete without pause is deprivation without economic remedy: the host loses all their invested work (photos, descriptions, pricing) with no way to reclaim it. This produces what Freud calls 'serious disorders' -- in marketplace terms, permanent churn accompanied by negative word-of-mouth.

elements.user_goal: Know that I can step away from hosting without losing what I have built, and come back on my own terms when I am ready.
elements.company_goal: Convert permanent host exits into temporary pauses, increasing the lifetime value of the host relationship and reducing the cost of re-acquisition by preserving the host's investment in their listing.
elements.time_budget: Pausing should take one action (a single toggle or button press). Reactivation should take no more than 2 actions (open listing, confirm reactivation). The host should never need to rebuild what was already built.
anti_goals: DO NOT require the host to explain why they are pausing. The pause must be frictionless; interrogation converts a temporary retreat into a confrontation.
DO NOT archive or degrade paused listings over time. A listing paused for 6 months should be as complete as the day it was paused.

DO NOT make reactivation conditional on additional compliance (re-verify identity, update photos, confirm pricing). The host already did this work; requiring it again is a civilizational tax on return.
elements.success_metric: Pause-to-reactivation rate: percentage of hosts who pause a listing and subsequently reactivate it. Target: above 40% within 6 months. Secondary: reduction in permanent listing deletions by 50% after pause feature introduction.

elements.title: Structure Guest Proposals as Civilizational Compliance Signals
elements.problem: Freud's Ch V observation that 'men are not gentle, friendly creatures' but carry 'a powerful measure of desire for aggression' describes the host's unconscious calculus when reviewing a guest proposal. Every proposal is from a stranger seeking entry to the host's private domain. The host's instinct is to distrust. The user stories document identifies that 'a well-structured proposal activates the host to respond' while 'a vague or incomplete one creates friction.' The mechanism is deeper than UX convenience: a well-structured proposal demonstrates that the guest has already submitted to the marketplace's civilizational rules (clear dates, explicit schedule, declared pricing intent). A vague proposal signals that the stranger has not yet renounced their instinctual chaos for marketplace order -- and therefore cannot be trusted with the host's space. The current platform allows proposals of varying structure quality, which means some proposals trigger the host's instinctual distrust rather than alleviating it.
elements.solution: Design the proposal system so that every proposal arrives pre-structured to demonstrate the guest's civilizational compliance. (1) Pre-populate proposal fields from the listing's own terms: dates, pricing, lease style. The guest confirms or adjusts, but cannot submit a blank or vague proposal. (2) Surface the guest's platform history prominently: completed leases, reviews received, verification status. Each of these is evidence that the guest has previously submitted to civilizational rules and honored them. (3) Include the guest's stated intent (work schedule, reason for stay) as a required field. A stranger who explains why they are coming is performing the civilizational ritual of declaring intentions -- it reduces the host's sense of instinctual threat. (4) Allow the host to counter-propose (adjusting duration, dates, or terms) as a controlled assertion of autonomy within the civilizational framework. The counter-proposal is the host saying 'I accept this stranger, but on my terms' -- a negotiated instinctual compromise that Freud identifies as the basis of all civilized coexistence.

evidence.quote: A well-structured proposal -- clear dates, schedule, pricing, intent -- activates the host to respond. A vague or incomplete one creates friction. Stories that push toward more structured, pre-populated proposal forms aren't just about UX, they're about making the cross-activation moment as clean as possible.
evidence.insight: The cross-activation framework identifies the mechanism: a structured proposal is not just easier to read but actively reduces the host's instinctual resistance to the stranger. The structure itself is the trust signal. Pre-population ensures every proposal meets this threshold.

evidence.quote: The bit of truth behind all this -- one so eagerly denied -- is that men are not gentle, friendly creatures wishing for love... but that a powerful measure of desire for aggression has to be reckoned as part of their instinctual endowment. The result is that their neighbour is to them not only a possible helper or sexual object, but also a temptation to them to gratify their aggressiveness on him.
evidence.insight: The host reviewing a proposal is performing Freud's exact calculus: is this stranger a 'possible helper' (good guest, reliable income) or a threat (someone who will damage the space, break rules, exploit the arrangement)? The proposal's structure answers this question before the host's instinct can default to distrust.

evidence.source: user-stories-initial-analysis.md, 'An experienced guest applying to a new host' section
evidence.quote: When someone who's already used Split Lease applies to a host who's never had a guest, that guest's reputation does the selling. Their history, their reviews, their familiarity with how things work -- it all reduces the host's anxiety.
evidence.insight: Prior civilizational participation (completed leases, reviews) is the strongest instinct-reduction signal available. The platform must surface this evidence prominently within the proposal itself, not on a separate profile page the host must navigate to.

elements.user_goal: Evaluate whether this person will respect my space and follow the rules, quickly and confidently, without having to chase down information or interpret vague signals.
elements.company_goal: Increase proposal acceptance rate and reduce response time by ensuring every proposal arrives with sufficient civilizational compliance signals to overcome the host's default instinctual distrust of strangers.
elements.time_budget: A host should be able to evaluate a proposal and decide to accept, counter, or decline within 90 seconds. All decision-relevant information (guest history, dates, pricing, intent, verification status) must be visible without scrolling or navigating away.
anti_goals: DO NOT allow proposals to be submitted without minimum required fields (dates, schedule, stated reason for stay). An incomplete proposal is an uncivilized signal that increases the host's instinctual resistance.
DO NOT bury the guest's platform history on a separate profile page. The trust evidence must be embedded in the proposal view itself.
DO NOT make counter-proposals feel like conflict. The counter-proposal is a negotiation, not a rejection. The UI should frame it as refinement, not confrontation.
elements.success_metric: Proposal response rate (accept + counter + decline, excluding no-response) within 48 hours. Target: above 80%. Secondary: acceptance rate of first proposals from verified guests with prior lease history. Target: above 50%.

elements.title: Use Repetitive Rituals to Contain Active-Lease Anxiety
elements.problem: The active lease is the phase of sustained coexistence with a stranger in the host's private domain. Freud observes that 'civilized society is perpetually menaced with disintegration through this primary hostility of men towards one another.' The equivalent in the host journey: every week the guest occupies the space, the host's instinctual anxiety about the stranger must be re-managed. Without structured mechanisms, this anxiety accumulates and either erupts as conflict or crystallizes into a decision not to re-list at retention. The host needs predictable touchpoints that confirm the civilizational order is holding -- that the guest is following the rules, the space is being respected, and the arrangement is working. Freud identifies the solution as 'order: a kind of repetition-compulsion by which it is ordained once for all when, where and how a thing shall be done so that on every similar occasion doubt and hesitation shall be avoided.'
elements.solution: Design the active lease phase around predictable, recurring rituals that provide the host with regular evidence of civilizational compliance. (1) Per-stay cleaning photo submissions: the guest uploads photos of the space at departure, visible to the host. This is not a chore but a ritual of respect -- it demonstrates that the guest treats the host's space as the host would. (2) Per-stay micro-reviews: after each stay cycle, both host and guest submit a brief assessment. This creates a cadence of mutual accountability that Freud would recognize as civilization's monitoring mechanism. (3) Arrival and departure notifications: the guest confirms arrival and departure within the Stays Manager, creating a predictable rhythm the host can rely on. (4) Weekly or per-stay dashboard summary: the host sees a snapshot of the most recent stay -- dates confirmed, cleaning photos submitted, any issues flagged. The pattern is: predictability reduces instinctual anxiety, and every confirmed ritual is evidence that the civilizational contract is holding.

evidence.quote: Order is a kind of repetition-compulsion by which it is ordained once for all when, where and how a thing shall be done so that on every similar occasion doubt and hesitation shall be avoided. The benefits of order are incontestable: it enables us to use space and time to the best advantage, while saving expenditure of mental energy.
evidence.insight: The Stays Manager's weekly cycle (arrival, stay, cleaning photos, departure, review) is Freud's 'order' made concrete. Each repetition confirms that the civilizational structure is holding, which reduces the host's mental energy expenditure on worry and doubt about the stranger in their space.

evidence.source: user-stories-initial-analysis.md, 'Urgency should surface first on the dashboard' section
evidence.quote: Unread proposals, pending actions, incomplete listings -- that's what a host needs to see the moment they log in. Everything else is secondary to what's waiting for them right now.
evidence.insight: Rod's dashboard principle applies to active lease management: the host needs immediate, structured visibility into the current state of their arrangement. If the dashboard surfaces the latest cleaning photo, the most recent review, and the next scheduled stay, it provides the 'order' signal that contains the host's instinctual anxiety about the stranger in their space.

evidence.quote: Civilized society is perpetually menaced with disintegration through this primary hostility of men towards one another... Culture has to call up every possible reinforcement in order to erect barriers against the aggressive instincts of men and hold their manifestations in check by reaction-formations in men's minds.
evidence.insight: The per-stay rituals (cleaning photos, reviews, notifications) are the platform's 'barriers against the aggressive instincts' -- they channel the host's anxiety into structured assessment moments rather than allowing it to fester as unstructured worry between stays.

elements.user_goal: Know that my space is being respected between my direct interactions with the guest, through regular, predictable evidence that the arrangement is working as agreed.
elements.company_goal: Reduce mid-lease conflicts and increase re-listing rates at retention by providing hosts with ongoing evidence that the civilizational contract is being honored, preventing the accumulation of unaddressed anxiety that drives permanent exit.
elements.time_budget: Each ritual touchpoint (reviewing a cleaning photo, reading a micro-review, checking the dashboard summary) should take under 30 seconds. The host should not need to initiate these checks; the platform should surface them proactively.
anti_goals: DO NOT make the rituals optional for the guest. A ritual that can be skipped is not a ritual -- it is a request, and its absence becomes a negative signal that amplifies the host's anxiety.
DO NOT overwhelm the host with notifications. The rituals should follow a predictable cadence (per-stay, not per-day) so the host can anticipate them rather than being surprised.
DO NOT use the rituals as surveillance mechanisms that the host can weaponize against the guest. The purpose is mutual reassurance, not asymmetric monitoring.
elements.success_metric: Ritual completion rate: percentage of stays where the full cycle (arrival confirmation, cleaning photos, micro-review) is completed by both parties. Target: above 70%. Secondary: correlation between ritual completion rate and host re-listing rate at retention.

elements.title: Build Host Identity as Civilizational Binding for Retention
elements.problem: Retention is the weakest phase in the host journey (the existing library has 44 mentions vs. 152 for active lease). The fundamental problem is psychological, not functional: at lease end, the host stands at Freud's fork between 're-entering civilization' (re-listing, accepting another stranger) and 'returning to primitive conditions' (reclaiming full autonomy, no guests, no platform). The user stories document does not address retention directly, which itself signals how little the current system invests in this phase. Freud's Ch V identifies 'the narcissism of minor differences' as the mechanism by which accumulated small grievances crystallize into a narrative of civilizational dissatisfaction. A host who had 12 good weeks and 1 bad week will, in retrospect, anchor on the bad week. Without a counter-mechanism, the subjective retrospective assessment defaults to the negative, and the host does not re-list.
elements.solution: Create a sense of host identity and community that makes the civilizational participation feel like membership, not just a transaction. Freud identifies that 'it is always possible to unite considerable numbers of men in love towards one another, so long as there are still some remaining as objects for aggressive manifestations.' The platform equivalent: (1) Build a host identity layer: hosting milestones (first guest, 10th stay, 1-year anniversary), visible hosting track record, and a host-facing narrative of their hosting history. This transforms the abstract transactional relationship into a personal identity investment. (2) Surface the cumulative economic value: total earnings, successful stays completed, positive reviews received. The host should see not just 'lease ended' but 'you have earned $12,000 across 3 guests over 18 months.' (3) Allow hosts to channel their civilizational frustrations outward rather than inward: provide forums, feedback channels, or structured complaint mechanisms that let the host express grievances without having to exit the platform. Freud's 'smaller communities' principle -- redirect aggressive energy toward external targets (competitors, bad actors) rather than the platform itself. (4) At the moment of lease end, present the re-listing path as a one-action continuation, not a new decision.

evidence.quote: There is an advantage, not to be undervalued, in the existence of smaller communities, through which the aggressive instinct can find an outlet in enmity towards those outside the group. It is always possible to unite considerable numbers of men in love towards one another, so long as there are still some remaining as objects for aggressive manifestations.
evidence.insight: A host community creates Freud's 'smaller community' effect: hosts united by shared experience can direct their accumulated frustrations outward (toward competitors, toward bad-actor guests as a category, toward the challenges of hosting) rather than inward (toward the platform itself). This psychological mechanism is the foundation of retention.

evidence.quote: A skeptical guest who sees verified reviews, ID checks, and real host history doesn't need the platform to convince them -- another user already did. Every review is a past guest activating a future one. The trust infrastructure is cross-activation infrastructure.
evidence.insight: Inverted for retention: the host's own hosting history becomes a self-activating retention mechanism. A host with 15 positive reviews and $8,000 in earnings has built an asset within the civilization. Abandoning the platform means abandoning that asset. Making the asset visible at the retention decision point raises the psychological cost of exit.

evidence.quote: Civilized man has exchanged some part of his chances of happiness for a measure of security.
evidence.insight: At retention, the host re-evaluates whether the security they received was worth the happiness they sacrificed. The platform must make the security tangible and cumulative: total earnings, successful stays, resolved issues, guest quality over time. If the host can see that the civilizational exchange was net-positive, the retrospective assessment favors re-listing.

elements.user_goal: Feel that my hosting history is a meaningful achievement, not just a series of transactions, and that my investment in the platform compounds over time rather than resetting with each lease.
elements.company_goal: Increase host re-listing rate by transforming the retention decision from a fresh cost-benefit analysis into a continuation of an established identity, reducing the psychological weight of the 'should I host again?' question.
elements.time_budget: The retention moment (lease-end summary, re-listing prompt) should present the cumulative hosting narrative in under 15 seconds. The re-listing action itself should take no more than 2 clicks.
anti_goals: DO NOT gamify hosting milestones with superficial badges that feel condescending. The identity layer must reflect genuine achievement (earnings, stays, reviews), not manufactured engagement.
DO NOT present the re-listing decision as a high-stakes moment. Frame it as a natural continuation, not a fork in the road. The lighter the decision feels, the more likely the host is to continue.

DO NOT use retention communications to introduce new platform demands (updated terms, new verification requirements). The retention moment is for reinforcing the value of what already exists, not for adding new renunciation costs.
elements.success_metric: Re-listing rate: percentage of hosts who complete a lease and create or reactivate a listing within 60 days. Target: above 50%. Secondary: correlation between cumulative hosting narrative visibility and re-listing rate.

elements.title: Make Platform Mediation Feel Like Justice, Not Bureaucracy
elements.problem: Freud identifies the 'first requisite of culture' as 'justice -- that is, the assurance that a law once made will not be broken in favour of any individual.' The platform's confirmation dialogs, approval flows, and rule enforcement mechanisms are this civilizational justice. But the host does not experience them as justice -- they experience them as bureaucracy. Every 'Are you sure?' dialog, every waiting period for guest approval, every required step in the date change flow is felt as the platform imposing its authority over the host's autonomy. The civilizational mediation that should feel protective instead feels restrictive. This is because the platform does not communicate WHY the mediation exists. The host sees the constraint but not the protection it provides. Freud warns that when civilizational rules feel arbitrary rather than just, they produce the antagonism that drives people to abandon civilization entirely.
elements.solution: Redesign every platform mediation mechanism to make the justice visible and the bureaucracy invisible. (1) For confirmation flows: instead of 'Are you sure you want to accept this proposal?', show 'This proposal includes a verified guest with 3 completed leases. Accepting will lock in your rate of $X/week for Y weeks.' The confirmation becomes a summary of the protection the host is receiving, not a question about their intent. (2) For waiting periods: instead of 'Waiting for guest response,' show what is happening during the wait -- 'The guest is reviewing your counter-proposal. Their history shows they typically respond within 24 hours.' Transparency converts bureaucratic delay into civilizational process. (3) For rule enforcement: when the platform prevents an action (e.g., cannot modify dates without guest approval), explain the reciprocal protection: 'Date changes require both parties to agree, which means the guest also cannot change dates without your approval.' Every constraint the host experiences should be framed as a constraint that also protects them. The pattern: make the justice bidirectional and visible at every enforcement point.

evidence.quote: The first requisite of culture, therefore, is justice -- that is, the assurance that a law once made will not be broken in favour of any individual.
evidence.insight: The platform's rules are Freud's 'law.' But a law that is not perceived as just produces antagonism. Every platform enforcement mechanism must make visible the justice it embodies -- that the rule applies equally to both parties and protects the host as much as it constrains them.

evidence.source: user-stories-initial-analysis.md, 'Messaging before proposals is a natural step' section
evidence.quote: The park analogy holds -- you check availability before committing. A message action reduces abandonment when someone isn't ready for a proposal. Having the option is better than having no action at all.
evidence.insight: The messaging step is a civilizational mediation mechanism: it allows both parties to assess each other before the formal proposal. When the platform provides this intermediate step, it makes the civilizational process feel natural rather than bureaucratic. The same principle applies to every rule: provide the 'park bench' (the informal, low-stakes intermediate step) before the 'commitment' (the formal, binding action).

evidence.quote: Civilization expects to prevent the worst atrocities of brutal violence by taking upon itself the right to employ violence against criminals, but the law is not able to lay hands on the more discreet and subtle forms in which human aggressions are expressed.
evidence.insight: The platform cannot prevent all bad guest behavior, but its mediation mechanisms should address the 'discreet and subtle forms' of aggression that Freud identifies: lateness, messiness, broken communication promises. Structured rituals (arrival notifications, cleaning photos, reviews) are the platform's version of addressing subtle aggressions that formal rules cannot reach.

elements.user_goal: Understand that the platform's rules protect me, not just constrain me, and feel that every requirement exists for a reason I can see and agree with.
elements.company_goal: Reduce host friction with platform processes by transforming perceived bureaucracy into perceived protection, increasing compliance rates and reducing support contacts about 'why do I have to do this?'
elements.time_budget: Each mediation explanation (why this confirmation exists, what happens during the wait, why both parties must agree) should be visible within the existing flow, not requiring a separate explanation page. Under 5 seconds of reading time per explanation.
anti_goals: DO NOT hide the bidirectional nature of rules. If the host must wait for guest approval, they must also know the guest must wait for host approval in equivalent situations.
DO NOT use legalistic language in mediation explanations. The host should feel protected by a fair arrangement, not bound by a contract they do not understand.
DO NOT over-explain. Brief, concrete explanations at the point of enforcement are more effective than comprehensive policy documents that no one reads.
elements.success_metric: Support ticket volume related to process confusion ('why do I need to do X?', 'why can't I change Y?'). Target: 30% reduction within 3 months of implementing visible justice framing. Secondary: host satisfaction rating with platform fairness.
